title: Female actors honoured at 11th Edition of Film Fest
description:
(28 Sep 2017) LEADIN
A festival dedicated to women in film has taken place in Morocco.
The International Women's Film Festival of Sale is in its 11th year and paid special tribute to three actresses.
STORYLINE
Standing in between two of her fans, Moroccan actress Souad Khouyi poses for photographs at the International Women's Festival of Sale (FIFFS).
Now in its 11th year the festival has grown into something of an institution, as Khouyi explains:
"This festival has developed very much, especially as we see that there is a second women's festival in Aswan," she says.
"The festival has become a tradition, so we are proud of this festival and also we are proud of our productions as Moroccan women of cinema."
As well as honouring women in front and behind the camera, FIFFS explores gender issues and looks at them in terms of social, cultural, economic and human aspects.
"Women are present in all issues, whether in theatre, cinema or television, because we can not live without a woman," says Moroccan actor Abdelkbir Rgagna. 
"We are very pleased with the existence of this festival which focuses on women and celebrates the work of women especially on an artistic level."
This festival was marked by tributes to three women for their outstanding film journeys: the Egyptian actress Rogina, the Moroccan actress Fadila Benmoussa and the Turkish actress Defne Halman.
Speaking after collecting her award on stage, Rogina highlights how much Egyptian film has developed since 2000, saying it is now "sophisticated" and calling the subjects of films "diverse and different".
Defne Halman says she prefers acting in films to other areas of the industry:
"I find that the roles have a lot more depth, one can prepare a lot better. It's an art form rather than something that you consume and throw away, it's something that can last over decades," she says.
Six films highlighting Moroccan talent were shown at the opening of the festival: "Riad of My Dreams" by director Zineb Tamourt, "Assia" by Malika Zairi, "Adam 99% Love" by Narjis Tahiri, "Amal" by Aicha Senna, "Badad" by Nadia Ghalia Lmhaidi and "No" by Dimna Bounaylat.
Other films from Europe, Latin America, Asia, Africa and across the Middle East were shown. 
The event is organised by the Bouregreg Association and runs from 25th to 30th September 2017.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/c708168141d2ec56e196c8b47e7bccde 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
